Information-Theory-2019.title: E2 201: Information Theory (taught as a graduate teaching assistant)
Information-Theory-2019.notesDesc: Below are the links to the notes that I prepared to help myself organise the material that I would teach every alternate week. I wish to mention here that these notes are exclusively written by me, and may not be correct in all respects. Thus, there is no guarantee that the notes are free from errors. I try as much as possible to make each of the notes error-free. If you do find any errors, logical, conceptual or otherwise, please notify me through email.

notesList.title: Hypothesis testing, total variation distance and KL divergence

Random-Processes-2017.title: E2 202: Random Processes (taught as a graduate teaching assistant)
Random-Processes-2017.courseInstructor: Prof. Utpal Mukherji and Prof. Parimal Parag
Random-Processes-2017.notesDesc: Below are some of the topics on which I prepared notes to assist the students in learning the topics taught in the course. I have also provided a link to the pdf of the notes. I wish to mention here that these notes are exclusively written by me, and may not be correct in all respects. Thus, there is no guarantee that the notes are free from errors. If you do find any errors, logical, conceptual or otherwise, please notify me.

notesList.title: Sample space, $\sigma$-algebra, example constructions of $\sigma$-algebras, “infinitely often” and “all but finitely many” events
Borel sigma algebra, random variables, CDF and its properties, construction of CDF from a probability measure, example constructions of random variables with respect to various sigma algebras
Functions of random variables: sum, min, Jensen’s inequality, Cauchy-Schwartz inequality

Sigma algebra generated by a random variable, simulation of CDFs on a computer, properties of joint CDFs, overview of Riemann and Lebesgue integrals, independence of random variables – definition and equivalent forms for jointly discrete and jointly continuous random variables
Conditional expectation, law of iterated expectations, geometric interpretation of conditional expectation as MMSE estimate, example problems
Moment generating functions, characteristic functions, jointly Gaussian random variables (or Gaussian random vectors)
Convergence of real sequences, modes of convergence of a sequence of random variables, Borel-Cantelli lemma, examples
Stationarity and wide-sense stationarity of stochastic processes, basics of discrete time Markov processes (DTMCs) – recurrence, transience, hitting times, stopping times
Miscellaneous problems on convergence of sequences of random variables

Programming-for-AI-2024.title: Programming For AI
Programming-for-AI-2024.courseInstructor: Dr. P. N. Karthik
Programming-for-AI-2024.courseDescription: This course offers a comprehensive introduction to the fundamentals of programming in Python, tailored for students embarking on their journey into AI and ML. Throughout the course, students will gain hands-on experience by implementing essential AI/ML tasks from scratch. The curriculum provides an in-depth exploration of fundamental Python data types, functions, loops, conditional statements, tuples, lists, and dictionaries. Additionally, students will be exposed to the powerful libraries in Python such as Pandas, NumPy, SciPy, Matplotlib, and Seaborn, equipping them with the tools necessary for sophisticated data analysis and visualization. As part of the exercise sets, students will engage in practical data analysis using real-world datasets from neuroscience, and implement core AI/ML tasks, including the training of artificial neural networks (ANNs), backpropagation, $k$-means clustering, and $k$-nearest neighbor classification, all from scratch. The course is designed to facilitate students who intend to pursue projects in deep learning and/or reinforcement learning in their subsequent semesters.

list.title: Strings and string manipulations.
Numbers and math operations.
Functions and loops.
Conditional logic and control flow.
Tuples, lists, and dictionaries.
Basics of Pandas.
Data visualisation with Pandas.
Data visualisation with Seaborn.
Introduction to object oriented programming in Python.
Assignment 1
Assignment 2
Final Project (for those students who do not choose to work on a topic of their choice)
Python Basics: A Practical Introduction to Python 3
list.authors: David Amos, Dan Bader, Joanna Jablonski, and Fletcher Heisler

list.title: Python tutorials at Real Python
Pandas from the Ground Up
list.description: A tutorial on Pandas presented at PyCon 2015

Probability-2024.title: Probability And Stochastic Processes
Probability-2024.courseInstructor: Dr. P. N. Karthik
Probability-2024.courseDescription: This is a graduate-level course on probability, with emphasis on development of concepts from a measure-theoretic perspective. In the first half, the course will introduce the students to the modern theory of probability, as expounded by Kolmogorov. In the second half, the students will be introduced to the theory of discrete time Markov chains and Poisson processes. See below for a comprehensive list of topics that will be covered in the course.

courseContents.title: Course Contents
courseContents.description: Functions, cardinality, countability, sample space, events, algebra, $\sigma$-algebra, probability measure, properties of probability measures, continuity of probability, conditional probability and Bayes' Theorem, independence of events, random variables and measurability, functions of random variables, expectations as Lebesgue integrals, independence of random variables, computer simulation of random variables, moment generating function, characteristic function, Borel-Cantelli lemma, strong law of large numbers, weak law of large numbers, central limit theorem, sequences of random variables and their convergence, Gaussian random vectors, discrete event random processes, discrete time Markov chains, state space and transition probability matrix, Chapman-Kolmogorov equation, recurrence and transience, stationary distributions, ergodic theorem, Poisson processes, merging and splitting of Poisson processes.

courseContents.title: Notes
courseContents.description: This section will be updated with the slides used in class. As the classes progress, the notes from previous lectures will be made available accordingly. The slides provided here do not include the handwritten annotations used for in-class explanations. If you wish to access the annotated slides, please contact me directly.

list.title: Course logistics.

Functions, cardinality, countability, examples of countable sets, proof of countability of $\mathbb{Q}$, uncountable sets, examples of uncountable sets, proof of uncountability of $\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}}$ via Cantor's diagonalisation argument.

Motivation for an axiomatic theory of probability -- Bertrand's paradox, definition of sample space, definition of algebra, need for $\sigma$-algebra, definition of $\sigma$-algebra, events, measurable sets, measurable space, measure, measure space, finite measure, infinite measure, probability measure, probability space.

Properties of probability measures, the union bound, the $\liminf$ (all but finitely many) event, the $\limsup$ (infinitely many or infinitely often) event, continuity of probability measure, probability measures on discrete (countable) sample spaces, probability measures on uncountable probability measures, Borel $\sigma$-algebra, $\mathscr{B}([0,1])$, Caratheodory's extension theorem, Lebesgue measure on $\mathscr{B}([0,1])$, $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$ and Lebesgue measure on $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$, Cantor set -- construction, properties, and Lebesgue measure.

Conditional probability measure, law of total probability, Bayes' Theorem, independence of a collection of events, independence of a collection of $\sigma$-algebras, Borel-Cantelli lemma, random variables and measurability, probability law of a random variable, cumulative distribution function (CDF) and its properties.
Homework 1 (topics: functions, cardinality, and countability).
Homework 2 (topics: sample space, algebra, and $\sigma$-algebra).
Homework 3 (topics: properties of probability measures, Borel $\sigma$-algebra, and Lebesgue measure).
Homework 4 (topics: conditional probability, independence, random variables).
Quiz 1.
Probability and Random Processes, Geoffrey Grimmett and David Stirzaker, 3rd Edition, 2001.
A First Course in Probability, Sheldon M. Ross, 10th Edition, 2019.
Discrete Event Stochastic Processes, Anurag Kumar, Department of ECE, IISc.
Probability Essentials, Jean Jacod & Philip Protter, Springer, 2004.
Foundations of the Theory of Probability, A. N. Kolmogorov, 2nd Edition, Dover, 2018.
Real Analysis, H. L. Royden and P. M. Fitzpatrick, 5th Edition, Pearson, 2023.
An Introduction to Probability Theory and its Applications, W. Feller, 2nd Edition, Wiley, 1991.
Probability and Measure, P. Billingsley, Anniversary Edition, Wiley, 2012.
Probability Foundations for Electrical Engineers, Krishna Jagannathan, NPTEL video lectures, IIT Madras.
Prof. B. V. Rao's notes on measure theoretic probability. See also his wonderful compilation of exercises.
Prof. Manjunath Krishnapur's course on probability theory taught at IISc.
